### Article Two
Each entity shall determine the fees, costs, and charges for the utilization of public facilities and services, by a decision from the competent authority of each entity, in accordance with the law regulating each of them, and after the approval of the Council of Ministers <orig>مجلس الوزراء</orig>.

### Article Three
The Ministers – each within their respective jurisdiction – shall implement this Decree-Law, and it shall come into effect from the date of its publication in the Official Gazette <orig>الجريدة الرسمية</orig>.

# Explanatory Memorandum
## For Decree-Law No. 1 of 2025
## Regarding Fees and Financial Costs
## For the Utilization of Public Facilities and Services
Given the continuous economic and social changes and the state's need for flexibility in managing financial resources and providing public services sustainably, there has become a need to repeal Law No. 79 of 1995 regarding fees and financial costs for the utilization of public facilities and services.
By repealing Law No. 79 of 1995 regarding fees and financial costs for the utilization of public facilities and services, which, if approved, will contribute to regulating the demand for these services, in pursuit of the principle of good management of public facilities and increasing the flexibility of ministries and government departments in establishing their own mechanisms for pricing public services and fees, while taking into account social justice and not affecting the minimum standard of living.
In the event of the law's repeal, the fees subject to it will be studied and analyzed by the concerned authorities and re-priced according to the cost of the service and the charge for utilization. This shall be by a decision from the competent authority in accordance with its law, and after presentation to and approval by the Council of Ministers <orig>مجلس الوزراء</orig>.

# Decree by Law No. 2 of 2025
## Approving the Accession of the State of Kuwait
## to the Arab Customs Cooperation Agreement

- Having reviewed the Constitution,
- And the Amiri Order issued on 2 Dhu al-Qi'dah 1445 AH, corresponding to 10 May 2024 AD,
- And based on the presentation of the Minister of Foreign Affairs,
- And after the approval of the Council of Ministers,
- We have issued the following Decree by Law:

### Article One
Approval is hereby granted for the accession of the State of Kuwait <orig>دولة الكويت</orig> to the Arab Customs Cooperation Agreement <orig>اتفاقية التعاون الجمركي العربي</orig>, signed in the city of Riyadh <orig>الرياض</orig> on 16 Rajab 1436 AH, corresponding to 5 May 2015 AD, the texts of which are appended to this Decree by Law.

### Article Two
Ministers – each within their respective jurisdiction – shall implement this Decree by Law, which shall come into force from the date of its publication in the Official Gazette.

Amir of Kuwait
**Mishal Al-Ahmad Al-Jaber Al-Sabah <orig>مشعل الأحمد الجابر الصباح</orig>**

Prime Minister
**Ahmed Abdullah Al-Ahmad Al-Sabah <orig>أحمد عبد الله الأحمد الصباح</orig>**

Minister of Foreign Affairs
**Abdullah Ali Abdullah Al-Yahya <orig>عبدالله علي عبدالله اليحيى</orig>**

Issued at Seif Palace <orig>قصر السيف</orig> on: 12 Rajab 1446 AH
Corresponding to: 12 January 2025 AD

## Explanatory Memorandum
for Decree by Law No. 2 of 2025
Approving the Accession of the State of Kuwait
to the Arab Customs Cooperation Agreement

Recognizing the importance of Arab customs cooperation <orig>التعاون الجمركي العربي</orig> and its effective impact on economic, commercial, and social fields through the establishment of appropriate rules for customs and administrative cooperation, enabling customs authorities to respond to emerging changes in trade and to benefit from the principles approved by the Arab Section and the Economic and Social Council <orig>المجلس الاقتصادي والاجتماعي</orig> in this regard, the Economic and Social Council <orig>المجلس الاقتصادي والاجتماعي</orig> of the League of Arab States <orig>جامعة الدول العربية</orig>, by virtue of its Resolution No. 2058 – D.A. 96 dated 3/9/2015, approved the Arab Customs Cooperation Agreement <orig>اتفاقية التعاون الجمركي العربي</orig>, which consists of (27) articles.
The aforementioned Cooperation Agreement <orig>اتفاقية التعاون</orig> entered into force on 3/8/2022, one month after the date of deposit of its ratification instruments by seven Arab states, in accordance with the provisions of Article (25) of this Agreement.
Article One of the Agreement defined the terms contained therein, and Article Two addressed the scope of application of the Agreement and the commitment of the contracting parties to provide mutual administrative and technical assistance among themselves.
Article Three stipulated administrative assistance provided upon request to the customs administration for the investigation of customs crimes or violations, while Article Four included cases of administrative assistance.
Meanwhile, Article Five dealt with customs control and the provision by the requested customs administration of customs control results to the requesting customs administration, utilizing information technology and e-commerce to enhance customs control.
Articles Six, Seven, and Eight addressed the process of exchanging customs information and documents, records, reports, or certified true copies thereof, and the Arab rules of origin.
Articles Nine and Ten stipulated the simplification and unification of customs procedures, the coordination of customs procedures among the contracting parties, and technical assistance and cooperation in customs work among the signatory states.
Article Eleven mandated the protection of intellectual property <orig>الملكية الفكرية</orig> and combating its infringement, as well as the establishment of specialized units for the protection of intellectual property rights.
Article Twelve required combating commercial fraud and counterfeiting, while Article Thirteen outlined combating money laundering and terrorist financing according to the competencies granted to customs administrations in this field.

Articles Fourteen, Fifteen, and Sixteen also addressed expertise and testimony before courts or judicial authorities concerning the application of customs legislation law, notification specific to assistance under this Agreement between customs administrations and methods of its provision, and investigations conducted in accordance with national legislation in the territory of the requested Party.
While Article Seventeen stipulated controlled delivery for the movement of illicit or suspicious goods exiting, entering, or transiting its territory, Article Eighteen stipulated the confidentiality, use, and protection of information.
Article Nineteen specified the exceptions under which assistance may be refused or its provision postponed when reasons for doing so exist.
Article Twenty addressed the costs and expenses borne by the requested Party or the requesting Party for assistance and how these costs and expenses are to be borne.
Articles Twenty-One, Twenty-Two, and Twenty-Three clarified the procedures for implementing the Agreement, dispute settlement, and general provisions considered as a minimum for cooperation that can be exchanged between the Contracting Parties.
Articles Twenty-Four, Twenty-Five, Twenty-Six, and Twenty-Seven stipulated ratification, accession, entry into force, amendment of the Agreement, and the possibility of withdrawal from it.

### Arab Customs Cooperation Agreement

The Governments of:
- State of Kuwait <orig>دولة الكويت</orig>
- Lebanese Republic <orig>الجمهورية اللبنانية</orig>
- State of Libya <orig>دولة ليبيا</orig>
- Arab Republic of Egypt <orig>جمهورية مصر العربية</orig>
- Kingdom of Morocco <orig>المملكة المغربية</orig>
- Islamic Republic of Mauritania <orig>الجمهورية الإسلامية الموريتانية</orig>
- Republic of Yemen <orig>الجمهورية اليمنية</orig>
- Hashemite Kingdom of Jordan <orig>المملكة الأردنية الهاشمية</orig>
- United Arab Emirates <orig>دولة الإمارات العربية المتحدة</orig>
- Kingdom of Bahrain <orig>مملكة البحرين</orig>
- Tunisian Republic <orig>الجمهورية التونسية</orig>
- People's Democratic Republic of Algeria <orig>الجمهورية الجزائرية الديمقراطية الشعبية</orig>
- Republic of Djibouti <orig>جمهورية جيبوتي</orig>
- Kingdom of Saudi Arabia <orig>المملكة العربية السعودية</orig>
- Republic of Sudan <orig>جمهورية السودان</orig>
- Syrian Arab Republic <orig>الجمهورية العربية السورية</orig>
- Republic of Somalia <orig>جمهورية الصومال</orig>
- Republic of Iraq <orig>جمهورية العراق</orig>
- Sultanate of Oman <orig>سلطنة عمان</orig>
- State of Palestine <orig>دولة فلسطين</orig>
- State of Qatar <orig>دولة قطر</orig>
- Union of the Comoros <orig>جمهورية القمر المتحدة</orig>
hereinafter referred to as the Contracting Parties.

## Preamble:

The Contracting Parties to this Agreement, concluded within the framework of the League of Arab States <orig>جامعة الدول العربية</orig>, consider that close cooperation between customs administrations has an effective impact on economic, commercial, and social fields by establishing appropriate rules for customs and administrative cooperation to enable customs to respond to major changes in trade, and recognizing the necessity of customs and administrative cooperation within the framework of the Greater Arab Free Trade Area <orig>منطقة التجارة الحرة العربية الكبرى</orig> and the Arab Customs Union <orig>الاتحاد الجمركي العربي</orig> to ensure the realization of benefits approved by Arab Summits and the Economic and Social Council <orig>المجلس الاقتصادي والاجتماعي</orig> in this regard, and whereas this Agreement aims to enhance cooperation between Arab customs administrations for the exchange of information and investigations to prevent any crimes and violations of customs legislation in the Contracting States that harm their interests in all aspects and other related fields, and being convinced that the existence of an Arab agreement encompassing the aforementioned objectives and principles, which the Contracting Parties are committed to implementing, will lead to a high degree of simplification and coordination of customs procedures, which is considered one of the primary objectives for increasing the efficiency and facilitation of intra-Arab trade, and recognizing the necessity of cooperation regarding matters related to the application of customs principles and practices of member states to combat customs crimes and violations, and acknowledging the increasing global interest in the security and facilitation of the supply chain in international trade, and the importance of achieving a balance between compliance and trade facilitation to ensure the movement of legitimate trade and to meet the requirements of states for protecting society and preserving customs revenues, and taking into account international agreements and conventions that include provisions and procedures for prohibition, restriction, prevention, and the adoption of special measures during control related to the transport of goods, and believing that combating customs crimes and violations is more effective under close cooperation between their customs administrations.
Have agreed as follows:## Article One
### "Definitions"
For the purposes of applying this Agreement, the words and phrases listed below shall have the meaning indicated opposite each of them as follows:

1.  **Agreement**: The Arab Customs Cooperation Agreement.
2.  **Contracting Parties**: The Arab states party to this Agreement.
3.  **Administration**: The General Customs Administration.
4.  **Customs Legislation**: Customs law, applicable laws, orders, and decisions, and provisions and regulations related to import, export, transit, storage, and circulation of goods, which are applied by the customs administrations of the Contracting Parties, as well as regulations related to prohibition measures, restrictions, and control procedures.
5.  **Customs Offence and Violation**: Any breach or attempted breach of customs legislation.
6.  **Customs Territory**: The area where customs legislation is applied with respect to the Contracting Parties.
7.  **Mutual Administrative Assistance**: Mutual customs procedures between customs administrations for the purpose of cooperation among them to apply customs legislation, prevent, investigate, and deter customs offences and violations.
8.  **Mutual Technical Cooperation**: Cooperation in all mutual technical customs fields between customs administrations for the purpose of applying this Agreement.
9.  **Customs Procedures**: The sum of procedures and practices carried out by customs administrations to apply customs legislation.
10. **Customs Control**: Procedures applied by customs to ensure compliance with customs legislation.
11. **National Legislation**: Means the laws, regulations, and standards imposed by the competent authorities of any of the Contracting Parties, which are in force within the territory of the country concerned, or those effective treaties to which the country concerned is deemed committed.
12. **Person**: Any natural or legal person.
13. **Information and Intelligence**: Data, whether processed or analyzed, and documents, reports, and other correspondence in any form, including their electronic, certified, or authenticated copies, related to customs matters.
14. **Request**: A written request from any customs administration in the Contracting Parties that includes the information for which assistance is requested in accordance with the provisions of this Agreement.
15. **Requesting Customs Administration**: The customs administration that requests assistance.
16. **Requested Customs Administration**: The customs administration from which assistance is requested.
17. **Fees**: Amounts collected by customs in exchange for providing a service.
18. **Customs Duty**: Amounts collected on goods according to the provisions of customs legislation.
19. **Official**: Any customs official or government employee appointed by the customs administration.
20. **Controlled Delivery**: Control procedures carried out around the process of exporting from, transiting through, or importing into the territory of one or more states, goods sent illegally or suspected as such, with the aim of detecting and identifying persons assisting in or committing customs offences and violations.
21. **Risk Management**: Adopting selective criteria for inspecting and examining imported and exported customs consignments.

## Article Two
### "Scope of Application of the Agreement"
For the purposes of applying the provisions contained in this Agreement, the Contracting Parties undertake to provide mutual administrative and technical assistance among themselves through their customs administrations in accordance with the provisions of this Agreement, for the proper application of customs legislation, and to prevent, detect, and combat customs offences and violations, and to ensure the security of the supply chain in Arab and international trade.

## Article Three
### "Administrative Assistance"
Subject to national legislation, the Requested Customs Administration shall, upon request, provide the Requesting Customs Administration with all information related to national customs legislation and procedures / useful for investigations: concerning customs offences or violations.

## Article Four
### "Cases of Administrative Assistance"
Subject to national legislation, the Contracting Parties shall exchange assistance automatically or upon request, all information related to administrative assistance, and in particular in the following matters:
1- Operations and goods that may constitute customs offences or violations in one of the Contracting Parties, provided that they include the following:
    a) The customs status of goods exported from the territory of the Requested Party and the customs procedures taken concerning them.
    b) Whether goods exported from the customs territory of the Requested Party to the customs territory of the Requesting Party were legally exported in accordance with the applicable conditions and procedures.

- c) If the goods transported in transit <orig>ترانزيت</orig> through the territory of any of the Contracting Parties have been transported legally.
- d) Illegal operations that have been observed or planned and are considered smuggling, equivalent to smuggling, or suspected by one of the Contracting Parties.
2- Persons who have committed or attempted to commit crimes or violations of customs legislation in one of the Contracting Parties.
3- Means of transport proven to be used for committing customs crimes or violations in the Contracting Parties.

### Article Five
**"Customs Control"**

1- Subject to national legislation and upon request, the requested Customs Administration shall provide the requesting Customs Administration with the results of customs control regarding the following:
    - a- Goods – whether in transit or in warehouses – used or suspected of being used in committing customs crimes or violations in the customs territory of the Contracting Party.
    - b- Means of transport used or suspected of being used in committing customs crimes or violations in the customs territory of the Contracting Party requesting assistance.
    - c- Places used or suspected of being used for committing customs crimes or violations in the customs territory of the Contracting Party requesting assistance.
    - d- Persons who have committed or are suspected of committing customs crimes or violations in the customs territory of the Contracting Party requesting assistance, especially those entering and exiting the customs territory of the Contracting Party requesting assistance.
2- The Customs Administration of any Contracting Party may carry out such control if it has reason to believe that planned, ongoing, or completed activities appear to constitute a customs crime or violation in the customs territory of another Contracting Party.
3- Customs control shall be limited to the extent necessary to ensure compliance with customs legislation.
4- For the purposes of applying customs control, Customs Administrations shall use risk management based on risk analysis to identify persons, goods, and means of transport that must be subjected to inspection, the necessary extent of inspection, and all other risks.
5- Customs control systems must include audit-based control procedures.
6- Customs Administrations shall use information technology and e-commerce to enhance customs control.

### Article Six
**"Exchange of Information"**

The Customs Administrations of the Contracting Parties shall exchange, automatically or upon request, all information regarding the following:
1- Cases that may involve harm to the economy, public health, public security, or a vital interest of one of the Contracting Parties.
2- Persons who have committed or attempted to commit crimes or violations of customs legislation, or are suspected of committing customs crimes or violations in one of the Contracting Parties.
3- Means of transport proven to be used for committing customs crimes or violations in one of the Contracting Parties.
4- Statistics on the movement of goods and means of transport exported or transiting between the Contracting Parties.
5- Scientific and technical information related to new trends, means, and methods used to commit customs crimes or violations.
6- The correct assessment of customs duties and taxes, the proper valuation of goods for customs purposes, the determination of tariff classification for goods, and the determination of the correct origin of goods.

### Article Seven
**"Exchange of Documents"**

1- The Customs Administrations of the Contracting Parties shall, automatically or upon request, exchange all available information that can be extracted from customs documents related to goods exchanged between these states and which constitute customs crimes or violations. This information may – if necessary – be sent in the form of identical or certified copies of these documents after verifying their accuracy and integrity as far as possible.
2- Exchange of documents and reports or certified copies thereof that contain all available information related to operations discovered or suspected of constituting a breach of customs legislation in the Contracting Parties.

### Article Eight
**"Rules of Origin"**

1- The Customs Administrations of the Contracting Parties shall cooperate with each other to ensure the application of the general provisions of the Arab Rules of Origin <orig>قواعد المنشأ العربية</orig> and their detailed rules, and related matters contained in those provisions such as direct transport, certificate and indication of origin, and administrative cooperation arrangements.
2- The Contracting Parties shall adopt subsequent control when there is doubt regarding the indication of origin.

# Article Nine
"Simplification of Customs Procedures"
1- The customs administrations in the Contracting Parties shall take the necessary arrangements to simplify, unify, and coordinate customs procedures in order to facilitate the movement of goods between the Contracting Parties, particularly through the following:
a) Adopting programs aimed at continuously updating customs practices and procedures to enhance and improve efficiency and effectiveness.
b) Adopting modern methods such as risk management, audit-based control procedures, and optimal use of information technology.
c) Cooperating with competent authorities and the private sector within the state.
d) Coordinating work procedures between customs ports in the Contracting Parties, especially land ports.
e) Exchanging reference prices for goods, if available, to be used as guidance during customs valuation.
f) Cooperating between customs administrations to unify the names and structures of fees for customs services on exchanged goods.
2- The Contracting Parties may provide greater facilities than those stipulated in this Agreement.

# Article Ten
"Technical Assistance"
1- The customs administrations in the Contracting Parties shall cooperate technically in customs work among themselves, particularly in the following cases:
a) Exchanging personnel with the aim of disseminating knowledge related to modern methods used in customs work.
b) Exchanging information and expertise in the use of technical equipment.
c) Mutual training of customs staff.
d) Exchanging experts.
e) Exchanging studies and research.
f) Implementing capacity-building programs and training courses on customs matters.
g) Exchanging necessary information regarding customs laws and regulations, administrative directives, procedures, and practices.
2- The Contracting Parties shall cooperate in benefiting from customs capacity-building programs organized by international organizations.
3- Enhancing Arab and international cooperation in the field of protecting intellectual property rights and combating commercial fraud and counterfeiting through relevant programs and courses and the exchange of expertise in related legislation.

# Article Eleven
"Protection of Intellectual Property Rights"
1- The customs administrations in the Contracting Parties may, automatically or upon request, coordinate among themselves with the aim of applying border measures to combat the infringement of intellectual property rights, within the limits of the capabilities or competencies granted to them under national legislation.
2- The customs administrations in the Contracting Parties may establish specialized units for the protection of intellectual property rights.

# Article Twelve
"Combating Commercial Fraud and Counterfeiting"
1- The customs administrations in the Contracting Parties may, automatically or upon request, coordinate among themselves with the aim of applying border measures to combat commercial fraud and counterfeiting, within the limits of the capabilities or competencies granted to them under national laws.
2- The customs administrations in the Contracting Parties may establish specialized units to combat commercial fraud and counterfeiting.

# Article Thirteen
Combating Money Laundering and Terrorist Financing
Subject to national legislation, the customs administrations in the Contracting Parties shall cooperate among themselves to exchange information and data regarding operations suspected of being related to money laundering, in accordance with the competencies granted to customs administrations in this field.

# Article Fourteen
"Experts and Witnesses"
1- The requested administration may allow its employees to appear as experts or witnesses before courts or judicial authorities in the territory of the Contracting Party requesting assistance on a matter related to the application of customs legislation law.
2- The customs administration requesting assistance must take all necessary measures to provide personal protection and security for experts and witnesses during their stay in the territory of its state pursuant to paragraph (1) of this Article.
3- The request for appearance must include sufficient data regarding the case for which testimony or expertise is required.

# Article Fifteen
"Notification of Requests"
1- Subject to the provisions of Article (3) of this Agreement, requests for assistance under this Agreement must be communicated directly between customs administrations. Each customs administration shall designate an official focal point for this purpose and provide its details to the General Secretariat of the League of Arab States <orig>الأمانة العامة لجامعة الدول العربية</orig>, which in turn shall communicate this information to the customs administrations in the other Contracting Parties.

2- The requesting Customs Administration <orig>الإدارة الجمركية الطالبة للمساعدة</orig> shall submit the request for assistance under this Agreement in writing or electronically, accompanied by any information deemed useful for fulfilling the request. The requested Customs Administration <orig>الإدارة الجمركية المطلوب منها المساعدة</orig> may request written confirmation for electronic requests. Requests may be made orally if circumstances so require, and oral requests must be confirmed as soon as possible in writing or by electronic means if acceptable to both administrations.
3- Requests submitted in accordance with paragraph (2) of this Article shall include the following details:
a) Name of the requesting Customs Administration <orig>الإدارة الجمركية الطالبة للمساعدة</orig>.
b) The relevant customs case, the type of assistance required, and the justification for the request.
c) A brief description of the case under consideration and the administrative and legal provisions applicable thereto.
d) Names and addresses of the persons to whom the request relates – if known.
4- If the requesting Customs Administration <orig>الإدارة الجمركية الطالبة للمساعدة</orig> requests a specific action or method, the requested Customs Administration <orig>الإدارة الجمركية المطلوب منها المساعدة</orig> shall comply with that request in accordance with its national legislation.
4- In the event that the requested Customs Administration <orig>الإدارة الجمركية المطلوب منها المساعدة</orig> does not have the required information, it may seek assistance from one of the competent authorities to obtain that information.

## Article Sixteen
"Investigations"
1- Specially designated officers of the requesting Customs Administration <orig>الإدارة الجمركية الطالبة للمساعدة</orig>, with the consent of the requested Customs Administration <orig>الإدارة الجمركية المطلوب منها المساعدة</orig> and in accordance with the conditions that the latter may impose – for the purpose of investigating customs crimes and offenses – may undertake the following:
a) Inspect documents, records, and other relevant data held by the requested Customs Administration <orig>الإدارة الجمركية المطلوب منها المساعدة</orig> to obtain information related to the customs crime or offense.
b) Obtain copies of documents, records, and other relevant data related to that customs crime or offense.
c) Participate as observers in all investigations conducted by the requested Customs Administration <orig>الإدارة الجمركية المطلوب منها المساعدة</orig> within its customs territory.
2- When officers of the requesting Customs Administration <orig>الإدارة الجمركية الطالبة للمساعدة</orig> are present in the customs territory of the other Contracting Party <orig>الطرف المتعاقد الآخر</orig> in the cases stipulated in paragraph (1) of this Article, they shall in all circumstances present proof of their official capacity.
3- While present in the territory of the other Contracting Party <orig>الطرف المتعاقد الآخر</orig> under the terms of this Agreement, officers shall be responsible for any offense they may commit and shall enjoy the same protection available to customs officers of that Contracting Party <orig>الطرف المتعاقد</orig> to the extent provided for in its national laws.
4- If the Customs Administration <orig>الإدارة الجمركية</orig> of a Contracting Party <orig>طرف متعاقد</orig> requests an investigation into operations violating its national customs legislation, the Customs Administration <orig>الإدارة الجمركية</orig> of the other Contracting Party <orig>الطرف المتعاقد الآخر</orig> shall initiate the investigation and inform the requesting Party <orig>الطرف الطالب للمساعدة</orig> of the results of that investigation.
5- Investigations shall be conducted in accordance with the national legislation in the territory of the requested Party's <orig>الطرف المطلوب منه</orig> state.
6- The official of the requesting Customs Administration <orig>الإدارة الجمركية لدى الطرف الطالب للمساعدة</orig> who is present in the territory of the requested Party <orig>الطرف المطلوب منه المساعدة</orig> shall act solely as an advisor and shall under no circumstances participate in the investigation, meet with persons being interrogated, or take part in investigation procedures.

## Article Seventeen
"Controlled Delivery"
1- The Contracting Parties <orig>الأطراف المتعاقدة</orig> may – by mutual arrangements – permit the movement of illicit or suspicious goods exiting from, entering into, or transiting through their territories – with the knowledge and under the control of the Customs Administration <orig>إدارة الجمارك</orig> – for the purpose of investigating or combating customs offenses or crimes.
2- If such movements cannot be carried out under the control of the Customs Administration <orig>إدارة الجمارك</orig>, it shall seek to initiate cooperation with the competent national authorities that possess such authority or refer the matter to those authorities.

## Article Eighteen
"Confidentiality, Use, and Protection of Information"
1- Intelligence or information obtained under this Agreement shall be considered confidential and shall be accorded the same degree of protection as provided for in the national legislation of the Contracting Party <orig>الطرف المتعاقد</orig> providing such intelligence and information.
2- Intelligence or information obtained within the framework of administrative cooperation under this Agreement shall be used exclusively for its purposes, unless authorized

3- If the execution of the request entails significant or unusual expenses, the Contracting Parties shall consult to determine the conditions under which the request will be executed and how the expenses and costs will be borne.
3- When exchanging personal data under this Agreement, the requesting Customs Administration shall provide it with the same level of protection that meets the requirements of the national legislation of the requested Customs Administration.

### Article Twenty-One
"Implementation of the Agreement"

1- Cooperation and mutual assistance mentioned in this Agreement shall be carried out by the Customs Administrations of the Contracting Parties. The executive mechanism for applying the provisions of this Agreement shall be determined by the Customs Administrations of the Contracting Parties.
2- For the purposes of this Agreement, the Customs Administrations of the Contracting Parties shall designate contact points. They shall also exchange lists of their names, job titles, addresses, telephone numbers, email addresses, and any other means of communication for these officials.
3- The Customs Administrations of the Contracting Parties shall take all measures to maintain a direct relationship between the officials responsible for investigations and combating customs violations.

### Article Nineteen
"Exceptions"

1- Assistance may be refused if it constitutes a violation of the sovereignty, security, public policy, or a major national interest of any Party, or if it involves a breach of industrial, commercial, or professional secrecy, or if it is incompatible with local, administrative, and legal legislations.
2- Assistance may be postponed if there are reasons to believe that it would impede an investigation, a judicial proceeding, or an ongoing procedure. In such a case, the requested Administration shall consult with the requesting Administration to determine whether assistance can be provided under provisions or conditions that the requested Administration may stipulate.
3- When refusing or postponing assistance, the reasons for refusal or postponement should be stated in writing as soon as possible.
4- In exceptional cases and for justified reasons, if the requesting Administration would not be able to fulfill a similar request from the requested Administration, it shall mention this in its request, and the fulfillment of that request shall depend on the decision of the requested Administration.

### Article Twenty-Two
"Settlement of Disputes"

Disputes related to the implementation of this Agreement shall be settled through negotiation between the Customs Administrations of the Contracting Parties as far as possible, and if that is not possible, they shall be settled through diplomatic channels.

### Article Twenty
"Expenses and Costs"

1- Subject to paragraphs (2) and (3) of this Article, the requested Party shall bear the ordinary expenses and costs arising from the implementation of this Agreement.
2- The requesting Party shall bear the expenses and allowances paid to experts and witnesses, as well as the costs of translators and interpreters who are not government employees.

### Article Twenty-Three
"General Provisions"

1- The provisions of this Agreement shall be considered a minimum for the cooperation that can be exchanged between the Contracting Parties.
2- The provisions of this Agreement shall not conflict with any mutual cooperation between the Contracting Parties of their own free will or pursuant to bilateral or multilateral agreements they have concluded or may conclude in this field.

# Decree-Law No. 3 of 2025
## Regarding the Care for Printing and Publishing the Holy Quran
## And the Prophetic Sunnah and their Sciences

- After reviewing the Constitution,
- And the Amiri Order issued on 2 Dhu al-Qi'dah 1445 AH corresponding to
10 May 2024 AD,
- And the Penal Code issued by Law No. 16 of 1960, and its amending laws,
- And Decree-Law No. 31 of 1978 regarding the rules for preparing
public budgets, monitoring their implementation, and the final account, and its amending laws,
- And Decree-Law No. 15 of 1979 regarding Civil Service,
and its amending laws,
- And Law No. 3 of 2006 regarding Publications and Publishing, and
Law No. 10 of 2011 regarding the establishment of the Public Authority for the Care of Printing
and Publishing the Holy Quran and the Prophetic Sunnah and their Sciences,
- And Decree No. 8 of 2025 amending the Decree regarding the Ministry of Awqaf and Islamic Affairs / Wizarat Al-Awqaf wal-Shu'un Al-Islamiyya <orig>وزارة الأوقاف والشئون الإسلامية</orig>,
- And based on the submission of the Minister of Awqaf and Islamic Affairs / Wazir Al-Awqaf wal-Shu'un Al-Islamiyya <orig>وزير الأوقاف والشئون الإسلامية</orig>,
- And after the approval of the Council of Ministers / Majlis Al-Wuzara <orig>مجلس الوزراء</orig>,
We have issued the following Decree-Law:

### Article One
Law No. (10) of 2011 referred to herein shall be repealed.

### Article Two
All rights and obligations of the Public Authority for the Care of Printing and Publishing the Holy Quran and the Prophetic Sunnah and their Sciences shall devolve to the Ministry of Islamic Affairs / Wizarat Al-Shu'un Al-Islamiyya <orig>وزارة الشئون الإسلامية</orig>. Employees working for the Authority shall also be transferred to the Ministry with the same grades, while retaining their salaries and financial benefits.

### Article Three
No official or private entity shall print the Holy Quran / Al-Mushaf Al-Sharif <orig>المصحف الشريف</orig> or import any edition thereof except with a permit from the Ministry of Islamic Affairs / Wizarat Al-Shu'un Al-Islamiyya <orig>وزارة الشئون الإسلامية</orig>.

---

### Article Twenty-Four
"Ratification and Accession"
1- This Agreement shall be ratified by the signatory states in accordance with their constitutional systems. Instruments of ratification shall be deposited with the General Secretariat of the League of Arab States / Jami'at Al-Duwal Al-Arabiyya <orig>جامعة الدول العربية</orig>, which shall prepare a record of the deposit of each state's instrument of ratification and notify the other contracting parties thereof.
2- Non-signatory states may accede to this Agreement by a declaration sent to the Secretary-General of the League of Arab States / Jami'at Al-Duwal Al-Arabiyya <orig>جامعة الدول العربية</orig>, who shall notify the other contracting parties of their accession.

### Article Twenty-Five
"Entry into Force of the Agreement"
This Agreement shall enter into force one month after the deposit of the instruments of ratification by seven of the signatory states. It shall apply to other states one month after the date of deposit of their instrument of ratification or accession with the General Secretariat of the League of Arab States / Jami'at Al-Duwal Al-Arabiyya <orig>جامعة الدول العربية</orig>.

### Article Twenty-Six
"Amendment of the Agreement"
This Agreement may be amended upon the request of one of its parties, or upon a proposal from the General Secretariat of the League of Arab States / Jami'at Al-Duwal Al-Arabiyya <orig>جامعة الدول العربية</orig>. Such amendment shall enter into force after the approval of the Economic and Social Council / Al-Majlis Al-Iqtisadi wal-Ijtima'i <orig>المجلس الاقتصادي والاجتماعي</orig> and the deposit of instruments of ratification by at least two-thirds of the signatory states.

### Article Twenty-Seven
"Withdrawal from the Agreement"
1- Any contracting party may declare its desire to withdraw from this Agreement by a written instrument deposited with the General Secretariat of the League of Arab States / Jami'at Al-Duwal Al-Arabiyya <orig>جامعة الدول العربية</orig>.
2- The withdrawal shall become effective for the state six months after the date of deposit of the instrument of withdrawal.
3- When a contracting party notifies its withdrawal from this Agreement in accordance with paragraph (1) of this Article, its commitment to the provisions of this Agreement concerning any request for cooperation submitted before the effective date of withdrawal shall remain in force.
This Agreement was drawn up in Arabic in the city of Riyadh on 16 Rajab 1436 AH corresponding to 5 May 2015 AD, in a single original copy to be deposited with the General Secretariat of the League of Arab States / Jami'at Al-Duwal Al-Arabiyya <orig>جامعة الدول العربية</orig>, and a certified copy shall be delivered to each state signatory to or acceding to the Agreement.

# Explanatory Memorandum
## for Decree-Law No. 3 of 2025
### Regarding the Care for Printing and Publishing the Holy Quran, the Sunnah of the Prophet, and their Sciences

Stemming from the pioneering role of the State of Kuwait <orig>دولة الكويت</orig> and its interest in spreading the Islamic call and what is related to it, such as the printing and publishing of the Holy Quran <orig>القرآن الكريم</orig>, the Sunnah of the Prophet <orig>السنة النبوية</orig>, and their sciences, this law has come to enhance the role of the Ministry of Islamic Affairs <orig>وزارة الشئون الإسلامية</orig> and entrust it with the responsibility for this noble work, given its accumulated experience and its ready capacities and capabilities that ensure its execution in the most complete manner, with high quality, and at a lower financial cost, in line with the general policy of the State <orig>الدولة</orig> under the current economic circumstances, which necessitate efficient performance of work while reducing public expenditure.
This law comprises seven articles:
Article One <orig>المادة الأولى</orig> of it stipulated the repeal of Law No. (10) of 2011 regarding the establishment of the General Authority for the Care of Printing and Publishing the Holy Quran, the Sunnah of the Prophet, and their Sciences <orig>الهيئة العامة للعناية بطباعة ونشر القرآن الكريم والسنة النبوية وعلومهما</orig>.
Article Two <orig>المادة الثانية</orig> of it provided for the transfer of all rights and obligations of the General Authority for the Care of Printing and Publishing the Holy Quran, the Sunnah of the Prophet, and their Sciences <orig>الهيئة العامة للعناية بطباعة ونشر القرآن الكريم والسنة النبوية وعلومهما</orig> to the Ministry of Islamic Affairs <orig>وزارة الشئون الإسلامية</orig>, as well as the transfer of all its employees working at the Authority, with the same grades, to the Ministry of Islamic Affairs <orig>وزارة الشئون الإسلامية</orig>, while retaining their salaries and financial benefits.
Article Three <orig>المادة الثالثة</orig> stipulated that it is prohibited for any official or private entity to print the Holy Quran <orig>المصحف الشريف</orig> or import any edition thereof except with a permit from the Ministry of Islamic Affairs <orig>وزارة الشئون الإسلامية</orig>. Article Four <orig>المادة الرابعة</orig> thereof also granted employees, to be designated by a decision from the Minister, the authority to enter shops and places that undertake the printing or display of copies of the Holy Quran <orig>المصاحف</orig>, to record violations, draw up reports, and refer them to the competent authorities.
Article Five <orig>المادة الخامسة</orig> stipulated that, without prejudice to any stricter penalty provided for by another law, anyone who violates the provisions of Article Three <orig>المادة الثالثة</orig> shall be punished with a fine of not less than three thousand Kuwaiti Dinars <orig>دينار كويتي</orig> and not exceeding five thousand Kuwaiti Dinars <orig>دينار كويتي</orig>, along with the confiscation of the infringing publications and the closure of the establishment for a period of not less than three months and not exceeding one year.
Article Six <orig>المادة السادسة</orig> entrusted the Minister of Islamic Affairs <orig>وزير الشئون الإسلامية</orig> with issuing the necessary decisions for implementing the provisions of this Decree-Law.
Article Seven <orig>المادة السابعة</orig> stipulated that the Ministers, each within their respective jurisdiction, shall implement this Decree-Law, and any provision conflicting with its provisions shall be repealed, and it shall come into force from the date of its publication in the Official Gazette <orig>الجريدة الرسمية</orig>.

## Article Four

Employees designated by a decision from the Minister shall have the right to enter shops and places that undertake the printing or display of copies of the Holy Quran <orig>المصاحف</orig> and books of the Sunnah of the Prophet <orig>السنة النبوية</orig>, to record violations, draw up reports, and refer them to the competent investigative authorities.

## Article Five

Without prejudice to any stricter penalty provided for by another law, anyone who violates the provisions of Article Three <orig>المادة الثالثة</orig> shall be punished with a fine of not less than three thousand Kuwaiti Dinars <orig>دينار كويتي</orig> and not exceeding five thousand Kuwaiti Dinars <orig>دينار كويتي</orig>, along with the confiscation of the infringing publications and the closure of the establishment for a period of not less than three months and not exceeding one year.

## Article Six

The Minister of Islamic Affairs <orig>وزير الشئون الإسلامية</orig> shall issue the necessary decisions for implementing the provisions of this Decree-Law.

## Article Seven

The Ministers – each within their respective jurisdiction – shall implement this Decree-Law, and any provision conflicting with its provisions shall be repealed, and it shall come into force from the date of its publication in the Official Gazette <orig>الجريدة الرسمية</orig>.

</footer># Decree-Law No. 4 of 2025

**Amending the Text of Article 441 of the Civil Code**
**Issued by Decree-Law No. 67 of 1980**

- Having reviewed the Constitution,
- And on the Amiri Order <orig>الأمر الأميري</orig> issued on 2 Dhu al-Qi'dah 1445 AH, corresponding to 10 May 2024 AD,
- And on the Civil Code <orig>القانون المدني</orig> issued by Decree-Law No. 67 of 1980, and amended by Law No. 15 of 1996,
- And based on the submission of the Minister of Justice <orig>وزير العدل</orig>,
- And after the approval of the Council of Ministers <orig>مجلس الوزراء</orig>,
- We have issued the following Decree-Law:

## Article One

The phrase (ten years) shall replace the phrase (five years) stipulated in Clause (1) of Article (441) of the aforementioned Civil Code <orig>القانون المدني</orig>.

# Explanatory Memorandum <orig>المذكرة الإيضاحية</orig>

**for Decree-Law No. 4 of 2025**

**Amending the text of Article 441 of the Civil Code <orig>القانون المدني</orig>**
**Issued by Decree-Law No. 67 of 1980**

Given that there is a difference between a right <orig>الحق</orig> and a lawsuit <orig>الدعوى</orig>, as a right is the debt for which the debtor's liability is engaged in favor of the creditor, the majority of Islamic Sharia <orig>الشريعة الإسلامية</orig> jurists <orig>فقهاء</orig> have unanimously agreed that rights <orig>الحقوق</orig> do not lapse by prescription <orig>التقادم</orig>, no matter how much time passes. According to this concept, the passage of time is not considered a reason for the legal <orig>شرعاً</orig> extinguishment of a right. As for a lawsuit <orig>الدعوى</orig>, it is the judicial means that enables the creditor to claim the right, and it is restricted by formal procedures, as it must be filed within a specific period. If this period is missed, it results in the inadmissibility of the lawsuit (non-acceptance). The Kuwaiti legislator <orig>المشرع الكويتي</orig> adhered to what the jurists <orig>الفقهاء</orig> unanimously agreed upon regarding the non-lapse of rights <orig>الحقوق</orig> by the passage of time, but adopted the passage of time for the prescription <orig>تقادم</orig> of a lawsuit <orig>دعوى</orig> claiming a right. In the Explanatory Memorandum <orig>المذكرة الإيضاحية</orig> to the Civil Code <orig>القانون المدني</orig> issued by Decree-Law No. 67 of 1980, it was indicated that the period required to prevent the hearing of a lawsuit <orig>سماع الدعوى</orig> – as a general rule – is fifteen years. However, it specified certain rights due to their special nature and stipulated a different prescription period <orig>تقادم مغاير</orig> for each, commensurate with the course of dealings therein, the customary period for their fulfillment, and taking into account the circumstances of those upon whom the obligation falls.

The aforementioned Civil Code <orig>القانون المدني</orig> stipulated in Article (441) thereof a prescription period <orig>مدة التقادم</orig> of five years for claiming taxes and fees. In pursuit of sound judgment, it was deemed appropriate to extend the period of inadmissibility for lawsuits claiming taxes and fees to ten years. And since the Amiri Order <orig>الأمر الأميري</orig> was issued on 10/5/2024, and Article (4) thereof stipulated that laws shall be issued by decree-laws <orig>مراسيم قوانين</orig>, therefore, the present draft Decree-Law <orig>المرسوم بقانون</orig> has been prepared. Article One thereof stipulated the replacement of the phrase "five years" with the phrase "ten years" as stipulated in Clause (1) of Article 441 of the aforementioned Civil Code <orig>القانون المدني</orig>. Article Two also stipulated the repeal of any text that contradicts or conflicts with the provisions of this Decree-Law. And the third and final Article obligated the ministers, each within their respective jurisdiction, to implement this Decree-Law, provided that it shall come into effect from the date of its publication in the Official Gazette <orig>الجريدة الرسمية</orig>.

**Article Two**
The Prime Minister and the ministers – each within their respective jurisdictions – shall implement this decree, and it shall come into force from the date of its issuance and be published in the Official Gazette.

Amir of Kuwait
Mishal Al-Ahmad Al-Jaber Al-Sabah <orig>مشعل الأحمد الجابر الصباح</orig>

# Decree No. 5 of 2025
Adding a new paragraph to the text of Article Four
of Decree No. (303) of 2005
Licensing the Establishment of Kuwait Technical College

- Having reviewed the Constitution,
- And the Amiri Order issued on 2 Dhu al-Qi'dah 1445 H, corresponding to 10 May 2024 G,
- And Law No. 34 of 2000 regarding the establishment of private universities,
- And Decree No. 303 of 2005 regarding the establishment of Kuwait Technical College,
- And the Executive Regulation of the Law on the Establishment of Private Universities, issued by Council of Ministers
- Decision No. (1106) of 2000, and its amending decisions,
- And the decision of the Private Universities Council (PUC 3/90-2024/4),
- And upon the proposal of the Minister of Higher Education and Scientific Research,
- And with the approval of the Council of Ministers,
We have decreed the following
**Article One**
A new paragraph shall be added to the text of Article Four of the aforementioned Decree No. (303) of 2005, which reads as follows:
((The College shall award a Bachelor's degree after the diploma under the (2+2) system in the following specializations, after fulfilling the academic accreditation requirements as determined by the Private Universities Council:
- Business Administration specialization, a branch of the Business Administration track at Kuwait Technical College (Business Administration – Accounting – Finance – Marketing – Information Systems – Supply Chain – Entrepreneurship). Cybersecurity specialization, a branch of the Information Systems and Technology track at Kuwait Technical College)).
**Article Two**
The ministers – each within their respective jurisdictions – shall implement this decree, and it shall come into force from the date of its publication in the Official Gazette.

# Decree No. 7 of 2025
## Regarding the Repeal of Decree No. (406) of 2011 Concerning the Social Repeal Office <orig>مكتب الإلغاء الاجتماعي</orig>

- Having reviewed the Constitution,
- And the Amiri Order issued on 2 Dhul-Qa'dah 1445 H, corresponding to 10 May 2024 G,
- And Law by Decree No. 15 of 1979 concerning the Civil Service, and its amending laws,
- And the Decree issued on 7 Jumada al-Awwal 1399 H, corresponding to 4 April 1979 G, concerning the Civil Service System, and its amending decrees,
- And Decree No. 401 of 2006 establishing the Supreme Council for Family Affairs <orig>المجلس الأعلى لشئون الأسرة</orig>, and its amending decrees,
- And Decree No. 406 of 2011 concerning the Social Repeal Office <orig>مكتب الإلغاء الاجتماعي</orig>, and its amending decrees,
- And upon the submission of the Minister of Social Affairs and Family and Childhood Affairs,
- And with the approval of the Council of Ministers,

We have decreed the following

### Article One
The aforementioned Decree No. 406 of 2011 is hereby repealed.

### Article Two
The competencies of the Social Repeal Office <orig>مكتب الإلغاء الاجتماعي</orig> stipulated in the aforementioned Decree No. 406 of 2011 shall be transferred to the Supreme Council for Family Affairs <orig>المجلس الأعلى لشئون الأسرة</orig>.

### Article Three
The permanent, temporary, and contracted employees of the Social Repeal Office <orig>مكتب الإلغاء الاجتماعي</orig> shall be transferred to the Civil Service Commission <orig>ديوان الخدمة المدنية</orig> to be distributed among all government entities with their same grades, salaries, bonuses, and allowances.

### Article Four
The ministers – each within their respective jurisdiction – shall implement this decree, and it shall come into force from the date of its publication in the Official Gazette.

# NOTE VERBALE
The Ministry of Foreign Affairs of Japan presents
its compliments to the Embassy of the State of
Kuwait in Japan
and has the honour to inform the latter that the
Government of Japan is prepared to take the
following measures concerning the waiver of
diplomatic and official visa requirements for
diplomatic and special passport holders:
1. Nationals of the State of Kuwait in possession
of valid diplomatic or special passports issued by
the Ministry of Foreign Affairs of the State of
Kuwait, seeking entry into Japan for the purpose
of exercising diplomatic or consular functions,
or official duties of the Government of the State
of Kuwait and such nationals holding the said
passports who are the members of their families
forming part of their respective households, may
enter Japan without obtaining a diplomatic or
official visa irrespective of the
duration of stay in Japan.
2. (1) Nationals of the State of Kuwait in
possession of valid diplomatic or special
passports issued by the Ministry of Foreign
Affairs of the State of Kuwait, seeking entry into
Japan for the purpose other than those referred
to in paragraph 1 above and with the intention of
staying in Japan for a period not exceeding
ninety (90) consecutive days, may enter Japan
without obtaining a visa.
(2) The waiver of the visa requirements under
sub-paragraph (1) above will not apply to any
nationals of the State of Kuwait who desire to
enter Japan with the intention of seeking
employment or permanent residence, or of
exercising a profession or other
occupation (including public entertainment and
sport for remunerative purposes).
3. The waiver of the visa requirements under
paragraphs
1 and 2 above does not. exempt nationals of the
State of Kuwait entering Japan from the
necessity of complying with the laws and
regulations of Japan concerning the entry,
stay, residence, exit and other control over
foreign nationals.

<header>
Kuwait Today / Al-Kuwait Al-Youm <orig>الكويت اليوم</orig> Issue 1722 Seventy-First Year 49
Sunday, 19 Rajab 1446 H – 19/1/2025
</header>
1. Japanese nationals in possession of valid diplomatic or official passports issued by the Ministry of Foreign Affairs of Japan, seeking entry into the State of Kuwait for the purpose of exercising diplomatic or consular functions, or official duties of the Government of Japan and such nationals holding the said passports who are the members of their families forming part of their respective households, may enter the State of Kuwait without obtaining a diplomatic or official visa irrespective of the duration of stay in the State of Kuwait.
2. (1) Japanese nationals in possession of valid diplomatic or official passports issued by the Ministry of Foreign Affairs of Japan, seeking entry into the State of Kuwait for the purpose other than those referred to in paragraph 1 above and with the intention of staying in the State of Kuwait for a period not exceeding ninety (90) consecutive days, may enter the State of Kuwait without obtaining a visa.
    (2) The waiver of the visa requirements under sub-paragraph (1) above will not apply to any Japanese nationals who desire to enter the State of Kuwait with the intention of seeking employment or permanent residence, or of exercising a profession or other occupation (including public entertainment and sport for remunerative purposes).
3. The waiver of the visa requirements under paragraphs 1 and 2 above does not exempt Japanese nationals entering the State of Kuwait from the necessity of complying with the laws and regulations of the State of Kuwait concerning the entry, stay, residence, exit and other control over foreign nationals.
4. The Government of the State of Kuwait reserves the right to temporarily suspend the application of all or any part of the foregoing measures for reasons of public policy including those relating to public security, order and health. Any suspension or lifting of the suspension will be notified immediately to the Government of the State of Kuwait through the diplomatic channel.
5. The Government of Japan reserves the right to refuse the entry into or stay in Japan to nationals of the State of Kuwait considered undesirable without providing the motives for its decision.
6. The Government of Japan may discontinue the foregoing measures by giving thirty (30) days' prior written notice to the Government of the State of Kuwait.
7. The Implementation of the above-mentioned measures will be commenced ninety (90) days after the date on which the Embassy of Japan in the State of Kuwait receives a diplomatic note from the Ministry of Foreign Affairs of the State of Kuwait confirming the completion of its internal procedures for the waiver of visa requirements for Japanese nationals holding diplomatic and official passports.
    The Ministry of Foreign Affairs of Japan avails itself of this opportunity to renew to the Embassy of the State of Kuwait in Japan the assurances of its highest consideration.

Tokyo, June 16, 2023

### Note Verbale

The Embassy of the State of Kuwait in Japan presents its compliments to the esteemed Ministry of Foreign Affairs of Japan and has the honour to inform the latter that the Government of the State of Kuwait is prepared to take the following measures concerning the waiver of diplomatic and official visa requirements for Japanese diplomatic and official passport holders.

In accordance with the provisions of Article (172) of the Bankruptcy Law No. (71/2020) and its executive regulations.

Requesting a judgment: First: To declare the bankruptcy of the first defendant company and to declare the bankruptcy of the second and third defendants in their capacity as general partners therein, and to appoint a bankruptcy administrator due to the lack of apparent assets of the defendant company, which confirms the disruption of its financial affairs, in the presence of the fourth defendant in his capacity. Second: To compel the defendants to pay the expenses and attorney's fees.
This is based on the claim that the plaintiff is owed by the defendant an amount of KWD 5,040 (five thousand and forty dinars) by virtue of 8 bank checks drawn on Burgan Bank <orig>بنك برقان</orig>, with the third defendant, in his capacity as the representative of the first defendant, being the debtor. These checks were due for payment in 2020 and were supposed to be cashed by the bank as they were issued against purchase invoices. Although the checks are currently due, the first defendant has refused to pay them. Out of a total of 37 checks, it has not fulfilled its obligations despite repeated demands. Consequently, the plaintiff obtained judgments No. (517 T M J/9, 364 T M J/9, 274/2 T M J/2, 10/2022, 429 T M J/9, 849 T M J/4, 272/2022 T M J/9, 260 T M J/3, 426/2022 T M J/3). The total amount awarded to the plaintiff in these judgments is KWD 5,315 (five thousand three hundred and fifteen dinars). An execution file was opened for them, but no amounts have been paid in the execution file due to the lack of apparent assets of the defendant company, which confirms the disruption of its financial affairs. In order to protect the plaintiff's financial rights, this lawsuit was filed.
Whereas the case was heard before the Commercial Civil Plenary Government Circuit/27, and in its session on 14/12/2023, the court of that circuit ruled that it lacked subject-matter jurisdiction to hear the case and referred it to the Bankruptcy Department at the Court of First Instance. The pronouncement of the decision was considered as notification to the plaintiff, the third defendant, and the fourth defendant. The Clerk's Office was tasked with notifying the first defendant and the second defendant of the judgment, and the decision on expenses and fees was reserved.
In implementation of the court's judgment, the case file was referred to the Bankruptcy Department and was heard before the bankruptcy judge. On 11/3/2024, he issued his decision to address the Bankruptcy Committee regarding the request to initiate the corresponding bankruptcy declaration procedures and its attachments, with the committee to provide the department with its opinion on the matter, along with the nomination of a trustee and an estimation of his fees should his appointment be decided in accordance with the law.
In implementation of the bankruptcy judge's decision, the Bankruptcy Committee submitted its report dated 22/5/2024, in which it concluded that: - The number of registered claims is 34 in the execution file against Oscar Arabia for Advertising, Publishing, and Distribution Company W.L.L. - There are no claims against the partners

No one appeared on behalf of the first defendant company, despite its legal representative having been notified.
And whereas the Court decided to reserve the case for judgment at today's session.
And whereas the Court initially notes that it is in the process of ruling on the request for the declaration of bankruptcy <orig>شهر إفلاس</orig> of the first defendant company, established in the case file as (Oscar Arabia for Advertising, Publishing, and Distribution Company / Majed Mohammed Al-Shammari and his Partner W.L.L. <orig>شركة أوسكار العربية للدعاية والإعلان والنشر والتوزيع/ ماجد محمد الشمري وشريكته ذ.م.م</orig>), for which the Bankruptcy Administration submitted a report. In light of that report, the Bankruptcy Judge <orig>قاضي الإفلاس</orig> issued his decision to refer the bankruptcy declaration request to the corresponding Bankruptcy Court <orig>محكمة الإفلاس</orig>. Therefore, the Court shall rule on this request as will be detailed below.
And whereas, as for the merits of the case, it is established in Article 1 of Bankruptcy Law No. 71/2020 that "For the purposes of this law, the following words and phrases shall have the meanings assigned to them: ...... Deficit in the financial position <orig>العجز في المركز المالي</orig>: The debtor's funds are insufficient to pay off their debts."
It is established in Article 2 of the same law that "The provisions of this law shall apply to:
1- Every natural person who has the status of a merchant.
2- Kuwaiti companies and branches of foreign companies, with the exception of private companies.
3- (.....)
It is established in the first paragraph of Article 13 of the same law that (The debtor may submit a request to the Bankruptcy Administration <orig>إدارة الإفلاس</orig> to initiate procedures for Preventive Settlement <orig>التسوية الوقائية</orig>, Restructuring <orig>إعادة الهيكلة</orig>, or Declaration of Bankruptcy <orig>شهر الإفلاس</orig> within a period not exceeding two months from the date of suspension of payments or from the date on which information became available to them suggesting they will be unable to pay their debts when they fall due, unless any of the creditors or regulatory authorities have submitted a request to initiate the procedures during the aforementioned period. Failure to submit the request within the periods specified in this paragraph shall not result in the non-acceptance of the request.)
It is established in Article 131 of the same law that (Subject to the provisions set out in the chapter on Preventive Settlement and the chapter on Restructuring, in which the Bankruptcy Judge may issue a decision to initiate bankruptcy declaration procedures, the Bankruptcy Judge shall issue his decision to initiate bankruptcy declaration procedures if the following conditions are met:
1- The debtor has suspended payments.
2- There is a deficit in the debtor's financial position.
3- The debtor's business is not viable for continuation.)

in the enforcement file.
- The total claims in the enforcement file amounted to 20,850 dinars (exceeding the minimum amount stipulated in Article 4 of Ministerial Resolution No. 81/2021 issuing the Executive Regulations <orig>اللائحة التنفيذية</orig> of Law No. 71 of 2020 issuing the Bankruptcy Law).
- The submitted documents were devoid of any financial data to ascertain the company's financial position or its ability to pay its debts. The committee then expressed its opinion that (-) the committee was unable to express an opinion on the financial situation and whether the company is capable of managing its business due to the lack of any financial data or documents showing the company's financial position.
- All claims received and registered in the enforcement file are against the company, and since the company's legal entity is a limited liability company and not a general partnership, the partners' liability is limited to their shares in the company and does not extend to their personal assets, unless other guarantees have been provided by the company.
- It recommended the appointment of the next trustee <orig>أمين</orig> on the roster from the list of licensed auditors at the Capital Markets Authority <orig>هيئة أسواق المال</orig> to inventory the debtor's assets and properties and take all necessary precautionary measures.
- The trustee's fees were estimated at 2,000 K.D.

After the submission of the Bankruptcy Committee's <orig>لجنة الإفلاس</orig> report, the Bankruptcy Judge issued his decision on 1/7/2024:
1- Non-acceptance of the request to initiate bankruptcy declaration procedures against the second defendant, Munira Zaal Mohammed Al-Shammari <orig>منيرة زعل محمد الشمري</orig>, and the third defendant, Majed Mohammed Al-Shammari <orig>ماجد محمد الشمري</orig>.
2- Acceptance of the request to initiate bankruptcy declaration procedures against the first defendant, German Printing and Packaging Company W.L.L. <orig>شركة المطبعة الألمانية للطباعة والتغليف ذ.م.م</orig>, and setting the date of the request submission, 10/9/2023, as the provisional date for the suspension of payments.
3- Appointment of the auditor, Abdul Latif Mohammed Jawhar Abdullah <orig>عبد اللطيف محمد جوهر عبد الله</orig>, registered in the roster of licensed auditors at the Capital Markets Authority, as a trustee whose mission shall be to inventory the assets and properties of the defendant company and the creditors' claims, prepare an updated financial statement for the said company, a list of debts, a liquidation and distribution plan, and take all necessary precautionary measures. The trustee's fees for his work were estimated at 2,000 K.D. (Kuwaiti Dinar <orig>دينار كويتي</orig>) for his hours worked from the date of issuance of this decision until the conclusion or closure of the bankruptcy proceedings.
4- Publishing and announcing the decision in the Official Gazette <orig>الجريدة الرسمية</orig> and notifying the concerned parties thereof.

Also on 1/7/2024, the Bankruptcy Judge issued his decision to refer the bankruptcy declaration request file as is to the Bankruptcy Court, along with the report, in preparation for a judgment declaring the bankruptcy of the first defendant, while tasking the Bankruptcy Administration with assigning the circuit and the session for its hearing and notifying the concerned parties.
In implementation of the Bankruptcy Judge's decision, the case file was referred to the corresponding circuit and registered under its current number.

The registered claims number 34 claims in the execution file against Oscar Arabia for Advertising, Publishing, and Distribution W.L.L. <orig>شركة أوسكار العربية للدعاية والنشر والتوزيع ذ.م.م.</orig>. and that the total claims amounted to 20,850 Dinars (exceeding the minimum amount stipulated in Article 4 of Ministerial Resolution No. 81 of 2021 issuing the Executive Regulations of Law No. 71 of 2020 regarding the Bankruptcy Law) and that the submitted documents were devoid of any financial data to ascertain the company's financial position or its ability to repay its debts, which made it impossible for the committee to express an opinion on the financial situation and whether the company is capable of managing its business due to the lack of any financial data or documents showing the company's financial standing), and since no representative of the first defendant company appeared before the court, despite being legally notified, to respond to the lawsuit with any plea or defense, the court therefore concludes that there is a deficit in the financial position of the first defendant company due to the absence of any financial data, and this deficit has resulted in its cessation of payment and the non-viability of its business. Consequently, the plaintiff's request to declare the bankruptcy of the first defendant company is based on a sound foundation, and it is necessary to rule in its favor, as will be stated in the operative part of the judgment.
As for the comprehensive expenses, including legal fees, since a bankruptcy lawsuit is a procedural action aimed at guaranteeing the rights of creditors, the court rules that these expenses be charged to the bankruptcy estate, in accordance with the provisions of Article 119/1 of the Civil and Commercial Procedures Law and Article 189, paragraph (c) of the Bankruptcy Law.

(For these reasons)
The Court has ruled: - To declare the bankruptcy of the first defendant / Oscar Arabia for Advertising, Publishing, and Distribution / Majed Mohammed Al-Shammari and his partner (W.L.L.) <orig>شركة أوسكار العربية للدعاية والإعلان والنشر والتوزيع / ماجد محمد الشمري وشريكته (ذ.م.م)</orig>, and to set 10/9/2023 as the provisional date for the cessation of payments. The Bankruptcy Administration <orig>إدارة الإفلاس</orig> shall register this judgment in the Commercial Register, publish a summary thereof in the Official Gazette, and announce it in accordance with the procedures followed in this regard. It has charged the expenses and the sum of ten dinars to the bankruptcy estate. In accordance with Article (8) of the Bankruptcy Law, the decisions issued by the bankruptcy judge shall be considered writs of execution under this law. The Bankruptcy Administration shall affix the executory formula to them, and they shall be enforceable immediately upon issuance and without notification.

Clerk of the Court Presiding Judge

It is stipulated in Article 132 of the same law that (in all cases where the bankruptcy judge issues a decision to initiate bankruptcy proceedings, the Bankruptcy Administration shall refer the file of the initiation request to the Bankruptcy Court within ten days from the date of the bankruptcy judge's decision to initiate the bankruptcy proceedings. A report shall be filed with the case file detailing the procedures undertaken since the submission of the request until the issuance of the decision to initiate the proceedings, along with a statement of the factual and legal grounds for the decision).
It is stipulated in Article 172 of the same law that (the state of bankruptcy is not established except by a judgment declaring bankruptcy.
The Bankruptcy Administration must, within ten days from the date of the judgment declaring bankruptcy, announce its operative part, publish it, and disclose it on the Boursa Kuwait <orig>بورصة الكويت</orig> stock exchange if the debtor is listed therein, and instruct the debtor to disclose it on its website and register it as specified in Article 33 of this law. It must also, within ten days from the date of that judgment, publish and announce a summary thereof).
It is also stipulated in Article 254 of the same law that (the provisions of this law shall generally apply to the procedures of preventive settlement, restructuring, and bankruptcy declaration submitted concerning corporate debts...).
It is stipulated in Article 13 of the Commercial Law that (1 - 2 .... Likewise, every company is considered a merchant, even if it undertakes non-commercial activities.)
It is established that the trial court has full authority to ascertain the facts of the case from the documents, evidence, and presumptions presented. It may deduce from the facts of the case and the conduct of the litigants the presumptions upon which it bases its conviction, provided that its deduction is sound, supported by evidence and grounds that have a firm basis in the case file, and leads to the conclusion it reached. The Court of Cassation may intervene if the conclusion drawn from those facts does not legally align with their implications.
(Appeal No. 704/2000 Commercial, session of 2/11/2002)

<header>

It is decided
### Article One:
First: Shapes shall be used with the following meanings:
1- Circle – Restriction
2- Hexagon – Caution
3- Triangle – Guidance and Awareness
Second: Colors shall be used as a primary element to enhance accessibility to their knowledge and meaning, as follows:
1- Red – Strict Restriction
2- Pink – Restriction
3- Amber – Strong Warning
4- Orange – Caution
5- Yellow – Awareness
6- Green – Safety

### Article Two:
The classification symbols guide viewers' ages to make informed decisions in accordance with cultural standards, as per the following table:

<table_caption>Age Classification Categories for Cinematic Films</table_caption>
<table>
| Classification | Symbol | Description | Viewing Content |
|:---|:---|:---|:---|
| G | <image>{ "description": "Green circle with letter G", "type": "icon", "data": "G" }</image> | Suitable for all ages | The content is within a positive framework and free from the effects of violence or threat, and primarily includes animated and family films. |
| PG | <image>{ "description": "Green triangle with letters PG", "type": "icon", "data": "PG" }</image> | Parental guidance is recommended | The content is generally safe, but may contain some violence, fear, or fantasy, but in a context suitable for children and families. |
| PG12 | <image>{ "description": "Yellow hexagon with letters PG12", "type": "icon", "data": "PG12" }</image> | Adult accompaniment is required for those under 12 years of age | The content is generally safe, but adults should assess the suitability of the content for those under 12 years of age due to the presence of some scenes that may not be appropriate for them. |
| PG15 | <image>{ "description": "Orange hexagon with letters PG15", "type": "icon", "data": "PG15" }</image> | Adult accompaniment is required for those under 15 years of age | The content includes scenes of violence, science fiction, natural disasters, simple romantic plots, dangerous scenes, and light war themes. |
| R15 | <image>{ "description": "Red circle with letters R15", "type": "icon", "data": "R15" }</image> | Only for those aged 15 and over | Contains sensitive topics such as violence, intense horror, severe violence, or political themes. |
| R18 | <image>{ "description": "Red circle with letters R18", "type": "icon", "data": "R18" }</image> | Only for those aged 18 and over | The content includes sensitive topics, and may contain extremely violent scenes, domestic violence, or sensitive political themes. |
</table>

### Article Three:
- The age classification system shall be used on printed tickets.

### Article Four:
This decision shall come into effect from the date of its issuance and shall be published in the Official Gazette.

Issued on: 14 January 2025 AD

for the Press, Publishing, and Publications Sector

*   And upon the Decree issued on April 4, 1979, concerning the Civil Service System and its amendments.
*   And upon Amiri Decree No. (417) of 2010 issued on October 25, 2010, regarding the establishment of the National Bureau for Academic Accreditation and Education Quality Assurance <orig>الجهاز الوطني للاعتماد الأكاديمي وضمان جودة التعليم</orig>.
*   And upon Ministerial Resolution No. (272) issued on October 3, 2012, concerning allowing Kuwaiti students to enroll for study outside the State of Kuwait only in universities for which a ministerial resolution is issued by the National Bureau for Academic Accreditation and Education Quality Assurance <orig>الجهاز الوطني للاعتماد الأكاديمي وضمان جودة التعليم</orig>.
*   And upon the decision of the Board of Directors of the National Bureau for Academic Accreditation and Education Quality Assurance <orig>الجهاز الوطني للاعتماد الأكاديمي وضمان جودة التعليم</orig> No. (7) issued on December 31, 2014, which includes the mechanism for issuing decisions related to identifying higher education institutions outside the State of Kuwait whose graduates' qualifications are permitted to be accredited.
*   And upon the decision of the Board of Directors of the National Bureau for Academic Accreditation and Education Quality Assurance <orig>الجهاز الوطني للاعتماد الأكاديمي وضمان جودة التعليم</orig> No. (2014/5) regarding the determination of criteria for selecting higher education institutions outside the State of Kuwait.
*   And upon Ministerial Resolution No. (2020/40) issued on February 17, 2020, regarding the updated list of higher education institutions in which enrollment is permitted for bachelor's and postgraduate programs in the United Kingdom.
*   And upon the letter from the Cultural Office in London No. (H.A./Academic Ban) dated November 29, 2024.
And based on the recommendation of the Committee for Proposing Standards and Reviewing and Updating Lists of Higher Education Institutions Outside the State of Kuwait in its twenty-first meeting held on December 23, 2024.
*   And upon the presentation of the Director General <orig>المدير العام</orig> of the National Bureau for Academic Accreditation and Education Quality Assurance <orig>الجهاز الوطني للاعتماد الأكاديمي وضمان جودة التعليم</orig>.
*   And upon what is required by the public interest.

It is decided
### Article One
To suspend the registration and enrollment of Kuwaiti students at all undergraduate and postgraduate levels in all specializations at The University of West of England, Bristol.
### Article Two
This decision does not apply to students who are already enrolled and continuing their studies before the issuance of this decision.
### Article Three
Any provision that contradicts the contents of this decision is hereby repealed.
### Article Four
This decision shall take effect from its date of issuance, and the competent authorities shall be informed and act accordingly. It shall be published in the Official Gazette.

Minister of Higher Education and Scientific Research
Dr. Nader Abdullah Mohammed Al-Jalal <orig>د. نادر عبدالله محمد الجلال</orig>
